bluebird.nn.NeuralNet¶

class bluebird.nn.NeuralNet(layers: Sequence[bluebird.layers.layer.Layer])¶

Bases: object

Creates a neural network model

Parameters

layers – list of layers of the newtwork, Type: Sequence[Layer]

Example

>>> net = NeuralNet([
            Flatten(input_size=(28, 28)),
            Dense(300, activation=Relu()),
            Dense(100, activation=Relu()),
            Dense(50, activation=Relu()),
            Dense(10, activation=Softmax())
        ])
__init__(layers: Sequence[bluebird.layers.layer.Layer]) → None¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

Methods

__init__(layers)

Initialize self.

backward(grad)

build([iterator, loss, optimizer])

Used to build the model

fit(inputs, targets, num_epochs)

Used to train the model

forward(inputs)

get_layers()

get_params_and_grads()

predict(inputs)

Used to predict values after you finished the training
build(iterator: bluebird.data.DataIterator = <bluebird.data.BatchIterator object>, loss: bluebird.loss.loss.Loss = <bluebird.loss.MSE.MSE object>, optimizer: bluebird.optimizers.optimizer.Optimizer = <bluebird.optimizers.sgd.SGD object>) → None¶

Used to build the model

Parameters

  • iterator – defines the way you want to iteratre over the data, default: BatchIterator() with the batch of 32 type: DataIterator

  • loss – defines loss function default: MSE() - mean squared error type: Loss

  • optimizer – defines how the weights should be updated default: SGD() - stohastic gradient descent type: Optimizer

Example

>>> net.build(optimizer=AdaGrad(lr=0.003), loss=CategoricalCrossEntropy())
fit(inputs: numpy.ndarray, targets: numpy.ndarray, num_epochs: int) → None¶

Used to train the model

Parameters

  • inputs – values used for training, Type: Tensor

  • targets – tarets, Type: Tensor

  • num_epochs – number of epochs you want to train

Example

>>> net.fit(X_train, y_train, num_epochs=20)
predict(inputs: numpy.ndarray) → numpy.ndarray¶

Used to predict values after you finished the training

Parameters

inputs – values you wish to predict, Type: Tensor

Returns: predicted values, Type: Tensor

Example

>>> net.predict(X_test)
